item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Well that's a disappointment. When I wrote this 2019 blog https://referee3.org/2019/12/25/data-sharing-should-be-mandatory-public-and-immediate/Nature (journals) had a solid data access requirement "authors are required to make materials, data, code, and associated protocols promptly available to readers without undue qualifications"although enforcement rarely worked.[UPDATE: so in fact this principle still exists. In practice they just give priority to the conditions upon access described below.]

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: [Updated]As described by @deevybee http://deevybee.blogspot.com/2024/05/are-commitments-to-open-data-policies.htmlenforcement remains anaemic.It seems that editors manage to give priority to contradictory procedural guidelines over the overarching principle they announced:"Any restrictions on the availability of materials or information must be disclosed to the editors [and] in the submitted manuscript.""The data availability statement must make the conditions of access... transparent to readers."
